question: Burning coal converts what type of energy into what type of energy?

content.source_1: [Coal stores energy in chemical bonds; when coal undergoes combustion, that stored chemical energy is released primarily as thermal energy (heat), often accompanied by light.]
content.source_2: [Combustion is an exothermic chemical reaction with oxygen in which the fundamental energy conversion is from chemical potential energy to thermal energy.]
content.source_3: [In coal-fired power plants, burning coal is used to generate electricity; the plant ultimately converts the energy in coal into electrical energy delivered to the grid.]
content.source_4: [Globally, most coal consumption occurs in the electric power sector for generating electricity.]
content.source_5: [The energy-conversion chain in a coal power station proceeds as: chemical energy in coal → thermal energy (steam) → mechanical energy (turbine) → electrical energy (generator).]
content.source_6: [Because of thermodynamic limits, only a fraction of the energy released when coal is burned can be converted into electricity; substantial energy is dissipated as heat.]
